channel.title: Secure OpenVPN increases speed
channel.description:
I'm at a hotel with awful free, non-secure wifi in Gatlinburg, TN, and needing to purchase tickets online, and with things like FireSheep on the loose I don't trust this connection, so I connected to an OpenVPN I had setup at home that I never got the opportunity to use before, and I was surprised when it seemed like pages loaded faster!
No VPN, Atlanta GA server (nearest): [img]http://www.speedtest.net/result/1427300879.png[/img] VPN, Cincinnati OH server (nearest): [img]http://www.speedtest.net/result/1427305094.png[/img] VPN, Atlanta GA server: [img]http://www.speedtest.net/result/1427306559.png[/img]
So I was even more surprised when it was confirmed, and the VPN is configured with security in mind, not even speed. I'm using bridging (as opposed to routing), [url=http://openvpn.net/index.php/open-source/documentation/howto.html#security]tls-auth[/url], and 2048-bit keys, all of which should slow things down. The thing that must make the difference is lzo compression is enabled on the line.
Also it was easy to setup, on the server, the laptop under Linux and Windows 7, and on both my and my wife's Android phones (running Cyanogenmod 7).
So, I'm impressed, awesome!

item.title: Secure OpenVPN increases speed
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:11, topic:409414”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=510698.msg3708066#msg3708066 date=1313173757]

That looks like the worst software in the world, also that doesn’t look like it sets up a secure SOCKS proxy tunneled through a SSH session anyway, so all your traffic would still be out there for anyone.

OpenVPN does run on windows you know, it was as easy to setup as it was on Linux, and works great.

It does, you set up rules for applications determining where all of the traffic is sent to. You can even throttle individual software/connections based on the rules you make. I’m not saying it’s the best, but it isn’t bad.

As far as OpenVPN running on windows, I was just saying that the above is an alternative (for better or for worse).

But it connects to what SOCKS proxy? Unless the SOCKS proxy is running on localhost, and tunneled through a secure channel (like an SSH session), then it is 100% useless security-wise, since all of that can be monitored too.

I just use the built in VPN on Win7. Does what I need well enough, don’t really need any more configuration - not yet at least.

Windows generally supports PPTP VPNs correct? I don’t think the default is secure either, and I don’t think it has an option for compression. It is supported in both Linux and Android though.

It’s what you said, but how can anything but DNS lookups be monitored?
[/quote]

SOCKS is not secure, so if you are on un-secured network X connected to a SOCKS proxy running on anything but localhost, anyone on network X can still see exactly what you are doing, and the administrator of X can even hi-jack anything on the connection and do whatever he wants with it.[/quote]
But SSH -D 808, for example, will create the tunnel listener on localhost…? Or am I missing something?

Read full topic

item.title: Secure OpenVPN increases speed
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

“Anyone on network X” is a bit disingenuous, but other than that you’re right

Read full topic

I just use the built in VPN on Win7. Does what I need well enough, don’t really need any more configuration - not yet at least.

SOCKS is not secure, so if you are on un-secured network X connected to a SOCKS proxy running on anything but localhost, anyone on network X can still see exactly what you are doing, and the administrator of X can even hi-jack anything on the connection and do whatever he wants with it.

item.title: Secure OpenVPN increases speed
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Yep. Supports PPTP. I can’t really find much configuration for stuff like compression, though I haven’t really had a proper look through it all.

Read full topic

item.title: Secure OpenVPN increases speed
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:3, topic:409414”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=510698.msg3706014#msg3706014 date=1313035425]
I’ve only used hotel internet once, and boy it usually sucks monkey cock. I usually just tunnel to my shell when on public networks.
[/quote]

I always used to just do something like this:
http://wiki.freaks-unidos.net/weblogs/azul/firefox-ssh-tunnel

But of course that only works with things that can communicate over a SOCKS proxy (doesn’t send DNS requests through the proxy either, generally), not on windows at all (unless I have an ssh client there set up with my private key), and not on anything else like Android phones etc. OpenVPN really seems like the way to go, because I’ve got it configured to send EVERYTHING through there, and it is supported on the operating system level, so applications don’t care![/quote]
http://widecap.ru/en/ is a nice windows alternative

Read full topic

item.title: Secure OpenVPN increases speed
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

T4_:

I’ve only used hotel internet once, and boy it usually sucks monkey cock. I usually just tunnel to my shell when on public networks.

I always used to just do something like this:
http://wiki.freaks-unidos.net/weblogs/azul/firefox-ssh-tunnel

But of course that only works with things that can communicate over a SOCKS proxy (doesn’t send DNS requests through the proxy either, generally), not on windows at all (unless I have an ssh client there set up with my private key), and not on anything else like Android phones etc. OpenVPN really seems like the way to go, because I’ve got it configured to send EVERYTHING through there, and it is supported on the operating system level, so applications don’t care!

Read full topic

@moparisthebest wrote:

I’m at a hotel with awful free, non-secure wifi in Gatlinburg, TN, and needing to purchase tickets online, and with things like FireSheep on the loose I don’t trust this connection, so I connected to an OpenVPN I had setup at home that I never got the opportunity to use before, and I was surprised when it seemed like pages loaded faster!

No VPN, Atlanta GA server (nearest):

VPN, Cincinnati OH server (nearest):

VPN, Atlanta GA server:

So I was even more surprised when it was confirmed, and the VPN is configured with security in mind, not even speed. I’m using bridging (as opposed to routing), tls-auth, and 2048-bit keys, all of which should slow things down. The thing that must make the difference is lzo compression is enabled on the line.

Also it was easy to setup, on the server, the laptop under Linux and Windows 7, and on both my and my wife’s Android phones (running Cyanogenmod 7).

So, I’m impressed, awesome!
